name: NPR
text:
Hurricane Laura is blamed for at least 10 deaths. The storm is estimated to have caused between $4 billion to $12 billion in damages, but experts say the price tag could have been far worse.
https://t.co/VoYEuFqOGF

name: NPR
text:
The DNC drew more TV viewers than the RNC, according to Nielsen figures. 

24.6 million people watched the night Joe Biden accepted his nomination â€” compared to 23.8 million for President Trump on Thursday.
https://t.co/dIHMpgjsSt

name: NPR
text:
BREAKING: The actor Chadwick Boseman, who starred in the "Black Panther," has died after a four-year battle with colon cancer. He was 43.
https://t.co/ZVF2YzdYja

name: NPR
text: Martin Luther King III: "There's a knee upon the neck of democracy and our nation can only live so long without the oxygen of freedom... So, if you're looking for a savior, get up and find a mirror. We must become the heroes of the history we are making." https://t.co/lnYj0esKhW https://t.co/jJEFT62gfo

name: NPR
text:
When Dr. Ayim Darkeh's mom asked him what it's like being a Black doctor, he told her "there are moments where it's amazing."

"Especially when I get my older patients who are members of the civil rights generation," he said. "They're so proud of me."
https://t.co/MSBR5LEq5o

name: NPR
text:
As debates rage over how to portray Kyle Rittenhouse, extremism researchers say part of the problem is that the teen gunman falls into a hard-to-define category of gunman that's increasingly showing up at protests â€” the self-styled vigilante.
https://t.co/dr6U0SQoKc

name: NPR
text:
The president has questioned the legitimacy of U.S. elections for years â€” although the reasons for his skepticism shift almost weekly.
https://t.co/I1XXrHiio7

name: NPR
text:
The Arecibo Observatory was substantially damaged this month. It's one of the largest radio telescopes in the world â€” and has been used to detect asteroids and other planets.

And that damage has big implications for slowing down research. #NPRShortWave https://t.co/46HpJyRsQf

name: NPR
text:
A Kansas teacher created a database after she couldn't find a cohesive picture of how COVID-19 was spreading in schools.

Now maintained by the National Education Association, it shares data that some schools prefer to keep quiet.
https://t.co/nrtpG6JnYP

name: NPR
text:
Deadly protests in Kenosha, Wisconsin, have brought to the forefront the racial and economic divide in this growing bedroom community.

"What you see is a lot of pain, a lot of fear," says the Urban League president.
https://t.co/a9l6uHL6nR

name: NPR
text:

name: NPR
text:
If our collective future were a movie, this week â€” when fires, floods, heat waves and disease outbreaks are layering on top of each other â€” would be the trailer, a climate scientist says.

"There is not a single ending that is good."
https://t.co/32pKNj32jN

name: NPR
text:
Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis held a roundtable with airline executives to extol the safety of air travel. Health experts agree the rate of infection from air travel appears low â€” but research on the topic is slim.
https://t.co/wOlGWCUXPR

name: NPR
text:
Katy Perry: "I guess authenticity is probably the No. 1 word or characteristic that I have leaned on my whole life because I was raised in a religious world where you weren't really allowed to talk about your feelings."
https://t.co/xnQ5KuM5Q5

name: NPR
text:
Opinion: As teams stop games to show support for Black Lives Matter, @nprscottsimon reflects on the tradition of athletes speaking out on behalf of civil rights and social justice.

"The greatest athletes know: children are watching." https://t.co/corVwmWzhw
